txt_1: Very humourous and engaging.  Makes learning about operating systems more approachable.  Isn't afraid to shoot down smart-ass questions -- a required trait in CS profs.
txt_3: Very fair overall in terms of workload and exam questions.  Course is detailed enough that busy work and tricky exam questions are not needed.
txt_4: Course load is a bit high for summer term (I think we had one less week of lecture time).
txt_6: Wish people wouldn't eat in class, but that's not really Dave's fault at all.

txt_1: CS 350 is such an important course.  Overall, really well taught.  Good examples from real life and industry & research to illustrate points.  Good, animated analogies, explanations.  Fun atmosphere.
txt_2: Time permitting, give more specific deeper explanations.  Course notes just asserts stuff.
txt_3: Really really important material fairly well taught.  Assignments were illustrative.
txt_4: No assignments for later sections at all.  Perhaps small written assignment?  Time permitting, more explanation of OS concepts.
txt_5: Such fun atmosphere, at least for morning class.

txt_1: The instructor does an excellent job of relating the course material to real life.  He employs good analogies as well.  His teaching philosophy is well thought-out.
txt_4: The assignments are too long.  Fewer, shorter assignments would be much better.
txt_5: The instructor has a positive attitude.

txt_1: The professor understood the learning process and was able to structure his lectures so that the instructed content was very clear.
txt_2: Lectures would be more interesting if they were less spoon-fed and more thought provoking, i.e.: more asking questions.
txt_3: Lots of hands on coding experience.
txt_4: Lots of the lecture material were things that could be considered common sense if you thought long enough about it.

txt_1: Youtube videos.
Kept the class entertaining.
txt_2: Sometimes goes through material too fast.  Do more examples on important topics.  Please provide hints on which material is important and what to avoid.  There is a lot of information to go through.
txt_4: Lack of proper coherent documentation for assignments, too hard and confusing due to not providing enough details.

txt_1: He is humourous, and he explains most of the course material very well.
txt_3: It is very informative and useful material.
txt_4: The course has too much work and takes up too much time for doing the assignments.  Also, some of the material is outdated.

txt_1: The most humourous prof I have met in this University, good lecture presentation all the time.  Good side notes on the slides.
txt_4: The assignments are more abstract (more high-level) than the course note.  I got lost sometimes when doing assignments and need to find online resource to make it clear.

txt_1: Explaining the material and making the lecture very interesting.
txt_4: The assignments were too long and without much guidance.

txt_1: Entertaining and engaging.  good real world examples.
txt_4: Needs better course notes, or more OS/161 relevant notes/documentation.  A diagram of OS/161's structure and what is/what isn't implemented would have helped a lot.
txt_5: The assignments should all be shifted one week earlier.  The start of the course was slow, the end was rushed.

txt_1: Excellent prof.
txt_2: More office hours would be nice.
txt_3: Good mix of theory and practice.
txt_4: I felt that wading through the given code was not directly relevant to the concepts taught in class even though it does prepare us for programming in groups.  I think that it might be nice to split the course into two with one focusing more on theory and the other on practice and students can pick either to satisfy core requirements.
txt_6: A better way of finding partners is needing.  People lie about their work ethic.

txt_1: Explains concepts really well, using personal experiences (Thrashing).  Very helpful during office hours, makes sure you understand what you were asking.
txt_4: One TA isn't enough, maybe have at least two TAs so we can see a graduate's point of view, other than the professors.
txt_6: Bring some coke zero for morning class.

txt_1: Always happy to answer questions.  Always gave appropriate and helpful examples by relating concepts to real objects (signals -> answering machine)
txt_2: Some key concepts are just hard to understand.  He does a good job explaining but more time could be spent on them.
txt_3: Understand, in a basic way, how the OS works.
txt_4: Assignments were very difficult, there was never enough materials to help with them.

txt_1: Makes lectures entertaining.
txt_3: good breadth and depth in operating system concepts.
txt_4: Difficult to balance workload with full course load.

txt_1: Dave was very enthusiastic and easy to pay attention to.  His use of metaphors to explain content was very helpful in understanding the material.  his pre-lecture videos and funny comments ensured I showed up for every class.
txt_2: Dave's expectations are set a little too high, which can be seen through the challenging midterm.  his explanations are sometimes (rarely) set too high, and sometimes moves too fast.

txt_1: Good jokes, very entertaining.
txt_2: Be less handwavy with explanations.  Draw more neatly on the board.
txt_4: Assignments are too long, and only focused on first half of the course.

txt_1: Kept the course interesting.
txt_2: Too fast.  Jumps around the slides which I found broke concentration.  More concrete examples would be great.

txt_1: Keeps the class entertained and interested.  Very enthusiastic.
txt_2: Give more detailed help on Piazza, not one line/word answers.
txt_4: Too much assignment work that is beyond things taught to lectures.  Notes were not applicable.

txt_1: Presented material in a 'light-hearted' manner; kept my interest in the material.
Excellent presentation of content, great examples for understanding difficult concepts.  Very approachable.  Hilarious.
txt_2: Nothing: one of the best profs @ waterloo especially for a summer term.
txt_3: Excellent teacher -> material taught very well.
txt_4: Lecture course notes outdated, difficult assignments, would help if course notes had a stronger focus for the content in A2.

txt_1: Good presentation of course material.  Actually has some charisma.  Pretty funny too.
txt_3: Printed course notes were much better than having to write our own.
txt_5: Positive class atmosphere, pretty easy going
